questions.prompt: Which of the following is NOT required for a set to be a vector space?
questions.explanation: A vector space requires closure under addition and scalar multiplication, additive identity and inverses, but NOT a multiplicative identity for vectors.

questions.prompt: The set of all $2 \times 2$ matrices forms a vector space.
questions.explanation: True. The set of all $2 \times 2$ matrices with standard matrix addition and scalar multiplication satisfies all vector space axioms.

questions.prompt: A subspace of a vector space $V$ must:
options: Be closed under addition and scalar multiplication
questions.explanation: A subspace must be closed under vector addition and scalar multiplication, and must contain the zero vector. It need not equal $V$ or have the same dimension.

questions.prompt: The null space of matrix $A$ is:
options: The set of column vectors of $A$
The set of row vectors of $A$
The set of all vectors $x$ such that $Ax = b$
The set of all vectors $x$ such that $Ax = 0$
questions.explanation: The null space (kernel) of $A$ is $\text{Nul}(A) = \{x : Ax = 0\}$, the solution set of the homogeneous equation.

questions.prompt: The column space of matrix $A$ is the set of all ____ of the columns of $A$.
questions.explanation: The column space Col$(A)$ is the span of the columns of $A$, i.e., all linear combinations of its columns.

questions.prompt: The span of vectors $\{v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_k\}$ is:
options: All linear combinations of the vectors
questions.explanation: Span$\{v_1, \ldots, v_k\}$ is the set of all linear combinations $c_1v_1 + \cdots + c_kv_k$ where $c_i$ are scalars.

questions.prompt: Vectors $v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_k$ are linearly independent if:
options: The only solution to $c_1v_1 + \cdots + c_kv_k = 0$ is all $c_i = 0$
questions.explanation: Vectors are linearly independent if the only linear combination that gives the zero vector is the trivial combination (all coefficients zero).

questions.prompt: If a set contains the zero vector, it cannot be linearly independent.
questions.explanation: True. Any set containing the zero vector is linearly dependent because $1 \cdot 0 = 0$ provides a nontrivial linear combination equaling zero.

questions.prompt: The dimension of the null space of $A$ is called:
questions.explanation: The nullity of $A$ is the dimension of its null space, equal to the number of free variables in $Ax = 0$.

questions.prompt: A set of vectors that spans a vector space $V$ and is linearly independent is called a ____ for $V$.
questions.explanation: A basis is a linearly independent spanning set. Every vector in $V$ can be uniquely expressed as a linear combination of basis vectors.
The standard basis for $\mathbb{R}^n$ has $n$ vectors, so $\dim(\mathbb{R}^n) = n$.

questions.prompt: If $\{v_1, v_2, v_3\}$ is a basis for vector space $V$, then $\dim(V) = $:
questions.explanation: The dimension of a vector space equals the number of vectors in any basis. Since the basis has 3 vectors, $\dim(V) = 3$.

questions.prompt: Every basis for $\mathbb{R}^n$ must contain exactly $n$ vectors.
questions.explanation: True. All bases for a given vector space have the same number of vectors (the dimension). For $\mathbb{R}^n$, every basis has $n$ vectors.

questions.prompt: The row space and column space of a matrix $A$ have:
questions.explanation: The row space and column space of any matrix have the same dimension, which is the rank of the matrix.

questions.prompt: If $H$ is a subspace of finite-dimensional vector space $V$, then $\dim(H)$ ____ $\dim(V)$.
questions.explanation: Any subspace has dimension less than or equal to the dimension of the containing space: $\dim(H) \leq \dim(V)$.
